mainmatter.p: \mathcal {M} is strongly \kappa-homogeneous if, given any A \subseteq \mathcal {M} with |A| < \kappa and an elementary map f:A \rightarrow \mathcal {M}, there is an automorphism f^*: \mathcal {M} \rightarrow \mathcal {M} such that f^*|_A = f.

We can observe that if \kappa is some infinite cardinality such that \mathcal {M} is strongly \kappa-homogeneous, then whenever A,B,B' \subseteq \mathcal {M} have |A|,|B|,|B'|< \kappa and B \equiv _A B', there is an automorphism f \in Aut( \mathcal {M}/A) such that f(B)=B'.
\mathcal {M} is strongly homogeneous if it is strongly | \mathcal {M}|-homogeneous.
